solution.text:
given that sum of the roots is greater than zeros but the product of roots is lesser than zero
\(\Rightarrow \alpha +\beta\gt\)0 and \(\alpha\times \beta\lt\)0
If \(\alpha\times \beta\lt\)0 \(\Rightarrow \)one root is negative and other is positive because \((+) \times (-) = (-)\)
let us say \(\alpha\) is positive and \(\beta \) is negative
\(\Rightarrow \) the point where the curve intersects the positive x axis is \(\alpha \) and where it cuts the negative x axis is \(\beta \)
Now \(\alpha +\beta\)>0, so \(\alpha \) is greater than than \(\beta \)
\(\Rightarrow \) the curve will cut the positive x axis at a greater distance from the origin than the distance at which it will cut the negative x-axis
Hence the number 3 graph is only suitable

content.text:
\(\alpha \) and \(\beta \) are the zeros of a quadratic equation whose sum of the zeros is greater than 0 but the product of zeros is lesser than 0.
From the given graphs choose the one(s) which are suitable to satisfy the above condition.
